recipes.title: Pussley Casserole
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian casserole from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: A baked casserole made from purslane (pussley), rich in vitamin C.

instructions.text: Cook purslane, drain, and chop fine.
Add eggs and cracker crumbs, or crumbled cornbread.
Bake.
Top with grated cheese just before serving.

notes: Can add bread crumbs, onion, poke greens, and beaten egg instead

recipes.title: Baked Nettles
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from The Foxfire Book 2
recipes.description: Nettles baked with ground beef and rice.

instructions.text: Cook nettles a long time.
Strain off liquid.
Chop fine.
Add ground beef, rice, and seasoning.
Bake at low heat until firm.

recipes.title: Stuffed Grape Leaves
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from Foxfire 3
recipes.description: Grape leaves stuffed with meat and rice.

instructions.text: Mix ground meat with cooked rice, onion, and seasonings.
Place filling on grape leaves and roll up.
Steam or bake until done.

recipes.title: Irish Potato Dumplings
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian recipe from Foxfire 2
recipes.description: Biscuit dumplings cooked in creamy potato broth.

instructions.text: Put quartered potatoes in pot, cover with water, add salt, pepper, butter, and milk.
Boil until potatoes are tender.
Roll biscuit dough out one-quarter-inch thick, cut in two-inch squares.
Drop into the rapidly boiling water the potatoes are in.
Cook dumplings about one minute, take the pot off the heat, and serve.

recipes.title: Fried Hornworms with Tomatoes and Basil
recipes.attribution: Eat the Weeds / David George Gordon
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - Tomato Tobacco Hornworms, credited to Eat-a-Bug Cookbook
recipes.description: Pan-fried tomato hornworms served atop fried green tomatoes with fresh basil.

instructions.text: Lightly fry the hornworms in a pan for a few minutes, being careful not to rupture the exoskeleton with high heat. Set aside to drain.
Sprinkle tomato slices with salt and pepper, then coat with cornmeal.
Fry tomato slices on both sides until lightly brown.
Top each tomato slice with one to two hornworms.
Crown each hornworm with a basil leaf.

notes: Hornworms should be purged (fed clean food) before cooking
Use low to medium heat to prevent rupturing

recipes.title: Classic Kamaro (Mole Cricket)
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - Mole Crickets article
recipes.description: Traditional Filipino preparation of mole crickets, known as kamaro.

instructions.text: Boil the mole crickets in vinegar and garlic.
Drain the crickets.
Remove legs, wings, and claws.
Sauté the bodies in oil with chopped onion and tomatoes until they reach a chocolate brown color.
Serve with cold beer on the side.

notes: Result should be crispy on the outside, moist in the middle
A traditional Filipino delicacy from Pampanga province

recipes.title: Philippine-Style Kamaro (Adobo Style)
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - Mole Crickets article
recipes.description: Mole crickets prepared adobo-style with soy sauce, vinegar, and optional coconut milk.

instructions.text: Numb the crickets and remove legs, wings, and claws.
Sauté crickets in garlic and onions.
Add soy sauce, vinegar, and hot pepper.
Optional: Add coconut milk to thicken the sauce.
Simmer until cooked through and sauce is reduced.

notes: Adobo-style preparation
Coconut milk adds richness

recipes.title: Lemon Grass Dog (Vietnamese Style)
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - Dog and Cat article (historical/cultural recipe)
recipes.description: A traditional Vietnamese preparation using lemongrass marinade. Dog meat is consumed in parts of Asia.

instructions.text: Mince four 3-foot stalks of fresh lemongrass (or use 8 oz frozen minced lemongrass).
Mix minced lemongrass with fish sauce, lime juice, and lime zest.
Chop meat into 1-inch pieces.
Add lemongrass marinade to meat and stir well.
Refrigerate mixture overnight.
Sauté, steam, or grill the meat. Alternatively, skewer chunks and roast in rotisserie oven.
Serve with jasmine rice, rice vermicelli, or baguette.

notes: Historical/cultural recipe from Vietnam
Dog meat consumption is traditional in parts of Asia

recipes.title: Cat Braisé (French Style)
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - Dog and Cat article (historical recipe)
recipes.description: A historical French-style braised preparation with artichokes and white wine. Cat was historically consumed during times of scarcity.

ingredients.prep_note: cut into serving pieces, dusted with flour, salt, and pepper

instructions.text: Prepare artichokes by snapping off outer leaves; trim stems and remove chokes; cut bottoms into quarters and soak in lemon-water.
Heat 2 tbsp olive oil in large casserole; brown seasoned meat pieces on all sides; remove to plate.
Discard remaining oil; add 1 tbsp fresh oil and bacon; sauté until cooked.
Add remaining oil, onion, and carrot; sauté 5 minutes.
Add artichoke quarters and garlic; stir 1 minute; add tomatoes and white wine.
Reduce heat until syrupy, stirring constantly, approximately 5 minutes.
Lay bouquet garni over vegetables; arrange meat pieces on top with accumulated juices.
Pour broth halfway up meat pieces; cover and simmer 1 hour or bake at 350°F for 1 hour.
Meat should be tender; turn pieces once during cooking.
Remove meat pieces and vegetables to warm platter; strain pan juices, reduce by one-third, and pour over.
Serve immediately; garnish with parsley if desired.

notes: Historical recipe - cat was consumed during wartime and famine in Europe
French braising technique

recipes.title: Fried Acorn Grubs
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - Acorn Grubs article
recipes.description: Simple fried grubs - soft and buttery when cooked properly.

instructions.text: Heat butter or oil over LOW heat. This is critical.
Add grubs and fry gently for a few minutes.
Do NOT use high heat - grubs will explode within a second in very hot fat.
Cook until soft and buttery.

notes: Raw grubs taste mild and chewy like fat
Cooked grubs are soft and buttery
Peak harvest is September after August rains

recipes.title: Puffball Crepes
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - Puffballs article
recipes.description: Thin-sliced puffball mushrooms used like crepes.

instructions.text: CRITICAL: Cut puffball from top to bottom and examine inside.
Interior must be marshmallow soft, pure white (never dark), with thin outer skin and no outline of mushroom inside.
Slice puffball very thin.
Brown slices with butter in a pan.
Use like crepes - fill and roll.

notes: Puffballs absorb flavor well but have little taste on their own
DANGER: Young Amanita (deadly) can look like small puffballs - always cut open to verify
Young Scleroderma (fatal) has hard white flesh inside

recipes.title: Breaded Deep-Fried Puffball
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - Puffballs article
recipes.description: Puffball slices breaded and deep fried like potatoes.

instructions.text: Verify puffball safety: cut open, check for pure white, soft interior with no mushroom outline.
Slice like potatoes.
Bread slices in flour.
Deep fry until golden.

notes: Can also cube for miso soup or cut into strips for stir fry

recipes.title: Fried Palmetto Weevil Grubs (Grugru)
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - Palmetto Weevil Grub article
recipes.description: Fried palm grubs - a tropical delicacy.

instructions.text: Slice or crack grub partway open around the middle.
This prevents explosion during cooking.
Fry in oil or butter until cooked through.
Alternatively, roast next to an open fire.

notes: Can also be eaten raw
Pupa stage is reportedly tastiest but rarest
Contains 3-7% protein and 10-30% fat
Find in dying palms with dead/bent growing tips

recipes.title: Agave Flowers with Scrambled Eggs (Oaxacan Style)
recipes.source_note: From eattheweeds.com - Century Plant article
recipes.description: Traditional Oaxacan preparation of agave flowers.

instructions.text: Harvest flowers during summer bloom.
Boil flowers until tender.
Mix boiled flowers with scrambled eggs.
Cook together until eggs are set.

notes: Flowers can also be roasted
WARNING: Raw agave juice causes dermatitis - wear eye protection when cutting
Avoid Agave lechuguilla (toxic species in TX/NM)

recipes.title: Squirrel Stew with Paprika and Greens
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Squirrel Stew with Paprika
recipes.description: A hearty Cajun-style squirrel stew with smoked sausage, paprika, greens and tomatoes.

instructions.text: Season squirrel pieces with salt and dust with flour.
Heat olive oil in a heavy Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Brown squirrels in batches without crowding. Set browned pieces aside.
Remove all squirrel from pot and add onions. Sauté 6-8 minutes until edges brown.
Add minced garlic and cook 1 minute. Stir in tomato paste and cook 2-3 minutes, stirring frequently.
Pour in white wine, vinegar, and approximately 1 quart water. Add savory, red pepper flakes, and paprika.
Add torn tomatoes and return squirrel to pot. Bring to simmer and cook approximately 90 minutes until meat falls from bones easily.
Remove squirrel pieces and pull meat from bones. Return meat to pot.
Add sliced sausage and greens; cook about 10 minutes until greens are tender (collards need 15-20 minutes).
Season to taste and serve with crusty bread.

notes: Chicken, turkey, or rabbit can substitute for squirrel
Better the next day like most stews

recipes.title: Cajun Turtle Sauce Piquante
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Turtle Sauce Piquante
recipes.description: A Cajun tomato-based stew with snapping turtle, one of the few Cajun dishes that commonly has tomato in it.

instructions.text: Make a blonde roux: Melt butter in a Dutch oven over medium heat. Add flour and cook, stirring constantly, until it turns the color of peanut butter (10-15 minutes). Do not let it get darker.
Add the holy trinity (onion, celery, bell pepper) and cook until softened, about 10 minutes.
Add garlic and cook 1 minute.
Add white wine and scrape up any browned bits.
Add crushed tomatoes, hot water, bay leaves, and Cajun seasoning. Stir well.
Add diced turtle meat. Bring to a simmer.
Cook gently for 1.5-2 hours until turtle is tender. The small dice makes tough turtle meat innocuous.
Season with salt, pepper, and hot sauce to taste.
Serve over white rice, garnished with green onions. Put hot sauce on the table.

notes: Turtle uses a blonde (peanut butter colored) roux and white wine, unlike dark meat which uses chocolate-colored roux and red wine
Alligator, frog legs, squirrel, or chicken thighs work as alternatives
Better the day after it's made

recipes.title: Braised Squirrel Aurora (Spanish Style)
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Braised Squirrel Aurora
recipes.description: Spanish-style braised squirrel with almonds and green olives.

instructions.text: Season squirrel pieces with salt and pepper.
Heat olive oil in a Dutch oven or braiser over medium-high heat. Brown squirrel pieces on all sides. Remove and set aside.
Add onion and cook until softened, about 5 minutes. Add garlic and cook 1 minute.
Add white wine and scrape up browned bits. Add stock, saffron if using, and bay leaf.
Return squirrel to pot. Add almonds and olives.
Cover and braise at a gentle simmer for 1-1.5 hours until squirrel is tender.
If using potatoes, add them in the last 30 minutes of cooking.
Remove bay leaf, adjust seasoning, and serve.

notes: Rabbit or chicken can substitute for squirrel
The almonds and olives are the defining flavors

recipes.title: Grilled Doves La Mancha
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Grilled Doves La Mancha
recipes.description: Spanish-style grilled doves with herbs and smoked paprika - the ultimate dove recipe.

instructions.text: Spatchcock the doves by cutting out the backbone and pressing flat.
Mix olive oil, paprika, garlic, thyme, rosemary, salt, pepper, and sherry vinegar to make a paste.
Coat doves thoroughly with the paste. Marinate at least 1 hour or overnight.
Heat grill to high. Clean and oil the grates.
Grill doves skin-side down first for 3-4 minutes until skin is crispy.
Flip and grill another 2-3 minutes. Breast meat should be pink (medium).
Rest 5 minutes before serving.

notes: Grilling is the best way to get crispy skin without overcooking the breast
Also works with pigeons, squab, teal, woodcock, rails, quail, or Cornish game hens
Serve medium (pink inside) - not well done

recipes.title: Grilled Deer Heart with Peppers and Onions
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Grilled Deer Heart
recipes.description: Grilled venison heart served with marinated peppers and onions - a celebration of the hunt.

instructions.text: Clean heart by trimming off fat, arteries, and silverskin. Slice into 1/2-inch steaks.
Mix olive oil, vinegar, garlic, rosemary, salt, and pepper.
Marinate heart slices for 30 minutes to 2 hours.
Grill peppers and onions over medium heat until charred and softened. Set aside.
Grill heart slices over high heat, 2-3 minutes per side for medium-rare.
Let rest 5 minutes. Slice against the grain and serve with peppers and onions.

notes: Works with elk, moose, antelope, or beef heart
Elk or moose heart feeds up to 6 people
Serve medium-rare to medium - overcooking makes it tough

recipes.title: Brunswick Stew
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Brunswick Stew
recipes.description: Iconic Southern stew traditionally made with squirrel, though many meats work.

instructions.text: Render bacon in a large pot. Remove and set aside.
Brown meat pieces in bacon fat. Remove and set aside.
Sauté onion until softened.
Add stock, ham hock, and browned meat. Simmer 2 hours until meat is very tender.
Remove meat and ham hock. Shred all meat and discard bones.
Add potatoes, cook 15 minutes. Add beans and corn, cook 15 more minutes.
Add tomatoes, Worcestershire, hot sauce, vinegar, and brown sugar.
Return shredded meat to pot. Simmer 30 minutes, mashing some potatoes to thicken.
Season with salt and pepper. Serve with cornbread.

notes: Squirrel is traditional but chicken is common now
Virginia claims this stew originated there, Georgia disputes this
Stew should be thick enough to eat with a fork

recipes.title: Wild Hog BBQ (Pulled Pork)
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Wild Hog BBQ
recipes.description: Slow-smoked wild hog shoulder for pulled pork - takes longer than domestic pork.

instructions.text: Mix dry rub ingredients (brown sugar through salt).
Coat shoulder with mustard, then apply rub liberally. Let sit overnight in refrigerator.
Set up smoker for 225-250°F. Use oak, hickory, or fruit wood.
Smoke shoulder fat-side up. Spritz with vinegar every hour after first 3 hours.
When internal temp reaches 165°F (usually 6-8 hours), wrap tightly in foil or butcher paper.
Continue cooking until internal temp reaches 200-205°F and probe slides in easily.
Rest wrapped for at least 1 hour.
Pull meat, discarding fat and bone. Mix with BBQ sauce or serve sauce on the side.

notes: Wild hog takes longer than domestic due to less fat
Internal temp of 200-205°F is key for proper texture
Can finish in 300°F oven if needed

recipes.title: Roast Snipe
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Roast Snipe
recipes.description: Simple roast snipe over a bed of sea beans - a rare treat with flavor all out of proportion to its size.
recipes.servings_yield: 2 servings as appetizer, or 1 as main

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 450°F.
Pat snipe dry and season inside and out with salt and pepper.
Rub softened butter over the birds and sprinkle with thyme.
Roast in hot oven for 12-15 minutes for medium-rare.
Rest 5 minutes before serving.
Serve over blanched sea beans or samphire if available.

notes: One snipe makes a great appetizer, four make a hearty meal
Snipe has intense flavor despite small size
Cook medium-rare to medium

recipes.title: Jesse's Hot Fried Snipe
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Fried Snipe
recipes.description: Southern-style fried snipe doused with a hot sauce, honey, butter and garlic glaze.

instructions.text: Soak split snipe in buttermilk for at least 30 minutes.
Mix flour with salt, pepper, and cayenne.
Heat oil to 350°F in a deep pan or fryer.
Dredge snipe in seasoned flour, shaking off excess.
Fry until golden and cooked through, about 4-5 minutes.
Meanwhile, melt butter with hot sauce, honey, and garlic.
Drain fried snipe and immediately toss with the hot butter sauce.
Serve immediately.

notes: Also works with doves and quail
From Jesse Griffiths' book Afield

recipes.title: Salmis of Snipe
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Salmis of Snipe
recipes.description: A classic French snipe recipe where birds are roasted, sauce made from bones, served with mushrooms.

instructions.text: Roast snipe at 450°F for 10-12 minutes until medium-rare. Let rest.
Remove breasts and legs from carcasses. Set meat aside, keeping warm.
Chop carcasses and sauté in butter over high heat for 5 minutes.
Add shallots and mushrooms, cook until mushrooms release liquid.
Add wine, stock, thyme, and bay leaf. Simmer 30 minutes.
Strain sauce, pressing on solids. Return to pan and reduce by half.
Add Cognac and reserved mushrooms. Season with salt and pepper.
Arrange snipe pieces on toast points and spoon sauce over.

notes: Classic French technique called 'salmis'
The sauce from the bones is the star
Works with woodcock, dove, or squab

recipes.title: Roast Woodcock with Cumberland Sauce
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Roast Woodcock
recipes.description: Classic roast woodcock with Cumberland sauce - the king of game birds.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 450°F.
Season woodcock inside and out with salt and pepper. Rub with butter.
Roast for 15-18 minutes for medium-rare (internal 130°F).
Meanwhile, make Cumberland sauce: Heat currant jelly with port, citrus zest and juice, mustard, and ginger until combined.
If you saved the livers, mash them on toast as a base.
Rest woodcock 5 minutes, then serve on toast with Cumberland sauce.

notes: Many consider woodcock the king of game birds
Traditionally served on toast spread with the bird's liver
Cook medium-rare - the meat should be pink

recipes.title: Pan-Seared Woodcock with Mushrooms
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Pan-Seared Woodcock
recipes.description: Simple pan-seared woodcock served with roasted mushrooms and Brussels sprouts.

instructions.text: Roast mushrooms and Brussels sprouts at 400°F with 2 tbsp butter until browned, about 20 minutes.
Season woodcock pieces with salt and pepper.
Heat remaining butter in a skillet over medium-high heat.
Sear woodcock breasts skin-side down for 2 minutes. Flip and cook 1-2 more minutes for medium-rare.
Remove breasts. Add legs and cook 4-5 minutes total.
Remove legs. Add shallot, cook 30 seconds. Add wine and thyme, scraping pan.
Serve woodcock over roasted vegetables with pan sauce.

notes: Breasts cook faster than legs - cook separately
Woodcock has a strong, gamey flavor in a good way

recipes.title: Pheasant with Mushrooms and Cream
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Pheasant with Mushrooms and Cream
recipes.description: Simple, homey pheasant breasts with fresh mushrooms, cream and brandy.

instructions.text: Season pheasant breasts with salt and pepper.
Heat butter in a large skillet over medium-high heat.
Sear pheasant breasts for 3-4 minutes per side until golden. Remove and keep warm.
Add shallots and mushrooms to pan. Cook until mushrooms are browned, about 5 minutes.
Add brandy and carefully ignite to burn off alcohol (or just let it reduce).
Add cream and tarragon. Simmer until sauce thickens slightly, about 5 minutes.
Return pheasant to pan, spooning sauce over. Cook 2-3 more minutes.
Slice pheasant and serve with mushroom cream sauce.

notes: Also works with grouse, chicken, or turkey breast
Don't overcook - pheasant dries out easily

recipes.title: Pickle-Brined Fried Pheasant
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Fried Pheasant
recipes.description: Pheasant brined in pickle juice then fried - tangy, tender, and crispy.

instructions.text: Brine pheasant pieces in pickle juice for 4-24 hours in refrigerator.
Remove from brine and soak in buttermilk for 30 minutes.
Mix flour, cornstarch, salt, pepper, paprika, and garlic powder.
Heat oil to 325°F - lower than typical fried chicken to account for leaner meat.
Dredge pheasant pieces in flour mixture.
Fry in batches for 12-15 minutes, turning occasionally, until golden and cooked through.
Drain on wire rack and season with salt while hot.

notes: Lower frying temperature prevents drying out lean game birds
Also works great with grouse and partridge
The pickle brine adds flavor and tenderizes

recipes.title: Duck or Goose Confit
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Duck Confit
recipes.description: Classic French duck confit - legs slowly cooked in duck fat until meltingly tender.

instructions.text: Mix salt, pepper, thyme, bay leaves, and garlic. Rub generously over duck legs.
Place legs in a container, cover, and refrigerate 24-48 hours.
Rinse legs and pat dry thoroughly.
Preheat oven to 250°F.
Place legs in a single layer in an oven-safe pot. Cover completely with duck fat.
Cook uncovered for 3-4 hours until meat is very tender and pulls easily from bone.
Let cool in fat. Store submerged in fat in refrigerator for up to 3 months.
To serve, remove legs from fat and crisp skin in a hot skillet.

recipes.pan_size: Dutch oven or deep baking dish
notes: Skin-on specklebelly and Canada goose legs are the gold standard
Do NOT make confit from breasts - they become livery
Stored in fat, confit keeps for months

recipes.title: Goose Breast with Orange (Greek Style)
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Goose Breast with Orange
recipes.description: Duck l'orange with a Greek twist using ouzo - works beautifully with goose.

instructions.text: Score goose breast skin in a crosshatch pattern. Season with salt and pepper.
Place breasts skin-side down in a cold pan. Turn heat to medium.
Render fat slowly for 10-12 minutes until skin is very crispy.
Flip and cook 3-4 more minutes for medium-rare (130°F internal).
Remove breasts and rest. Pour off most fat.
Add orange juice, zest, ouzo, honey, and stock to pan. Reduce by half.
Remove from heat and whisk in cold butter to make glossy sauce.
Slice goose breast against the grain and serve with sauce.

notes: Start skin-side down in a COLD pan for crispiest skin
Goose and duck should be served medium-rare like steak
Ouzo adds anise flavor - substitute Pernod or skip if unavailable

recipes.title: German Rabbit Stew with Lemon
recipes.attribution: Hank Shaw / Hunter Angler Gardener Cook
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - German Rabbit Stew
recipes.description: A light, brothy German rabbit stew with lemon, bay leaves, capers and sour cream.

instructions.text: Season rabbit pieces with salt and pepper.
Brown rabbit in butter over medium-high heat. Remove and set aside.
Sauté onion until softened, about 5 minutes.
Add stock, wine, bay leaves, and lemon zest. Return rabbit to pot.
Simmer covered for 1-1.5 hours until rabbit is tender.
Remove rabbit. Add lemon juice and capers to broth.
Temper sour cream with a little hot broth, then stir into pot.
Return rabbit, garnish with parsley. Serve with roasted potatoes.

notes: Different from hasenpfeffer - this is light and brothy
Rabbits are mild white meat, hares are strongly flavored red meat
Knockout dish with roasted potatoes

recipes.title: Siberian Bear Pelmeni
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Russian dumplings traditionally made with bear meat
recipes.description: Traditional Siberian dumplings with bear meat and lots of onion. The original pelmeni were made by bear hunters and frozen in the snow for the trail.

instructions.text: Make the dough: Mix flour with egg yolks, buttermilk, and water. Knead until smooth. Let rest 30 minutes.
Make the filling: Combine ground bear meat with onion, garlic, salt pork, salt, and pepper. Mix well.
Roll dough thin and cut into 3-inch rounds.
Place a small spoonful of filling in center of each round.
Fold in half and pinch edges to seal, then bring corners together to form the classic pelmeni shape.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.
Boil pelmeni for 6-8 minutes to ensure bear meat is fully cooked.
Serve with sour cream mixed with dill and black pepper.

notes: Use a lot of onion - it's a defining feature of these dumplings
Can substitute pork or beef for bear
Traditionally made with sourdough using whey

recipes.title: Chinese Red Braised Pork or Bear
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Classic Chinese dish adapted for wild game
recipes.description: Sweet-savory braised fatty meat with star anise and dark soy sauce. Works beautifully with fat wild pigs or bear belly.

instructions.text: Bring a large pot of water to boil. Boil the whole slab of belly for 5 minutes. Remove and let cool.
Cut the meat into 2-inch cubes.
Mix sugar with 3 tablespoons water until dissolved.
In a wok or Dutch oven, heat the sugar syrup over medium heat until it turns amber, about 5 minutes.
Add the par-cooked meat and turn to coat with the caramelized sugar.
Add garlic, ginger, and scallions. Stir for 1 minute.
Add both soy sauces, wine, star anise, and enough water to barely cover the meat.
Bring to a boil, then reduce to a gentle simmer.
Simmer for 90 minutes for pork, up to 3 hours for wild hog or bear, until meat is very tender.
Serve over steamed jasmine rice.

notes: Dark soy sauce has a slight molasses sweetness different from regular soy
Wild game may take longer than domestic pork
Any fatty cut works - shoulder is also good

recipes.title: French Fried Frog Legs
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - French-style fried frog legs with butter sauce
recipes.description: Classic French preparation of frog legs, lightly fried in clarified butter and served with garlic parsley butter sauce.

instructions.text: Soak frog legs in milk in the refrigerator for 1 hour. (Skip for store-bought legs.)
Remove legs from milk, pat dry, and season with salt and pepper.
Dredge legs lightly in flour, shaking off excess.
Heat clarified butter in a large skillet over medium-high heat until you see a wisp of smoke (about 340°F).
Add frog legs and cook 3-4 minutes per side until golden brown and cooked through.
Remove legs to a warm platter.
Add regular butter to the pan, then garlic. Sauté 30 seconds.
Add parsley and lemon juice, swirl to combine.
Pour sauce over frog legs and serve immediately.

notes: Frog legs taste like a combination of chicken breast, shrimp, and crab
Use clarified butter to fry - higher smoke point
Good fresh ingredients are key - no wilty parsley

recipes.title: Chinese Stir-Fried Frog Legs
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - An amalgam of General Tso's, kung pao, and black bean styles
recipes.description: Battered and fried frog legs tossed in a sweet-spicy sauce with vegetables. A fusion of Chinese-American classics.

instructions.text: Whisk egg yolks with 2 tbsp soy sauce. Marinate frog legs while prepping other ingredients.
Mix sauce ingredients: chile bean sauce, 2 tbsp soy sauce, vinegar, sugar, stock, and 1 tbsp cornstarch.
Remove frog legs from marinade and dust with remaining cornstarch.
Heat oil to 350°F. Fry frog legs in batches until golden, 3-5 minutes. Drain.
Pour off all but 2 tbsp oil from wok.
Get wok very hot. Add garlic, ginger, and shallot. Stir-fry 30 seconds.
Add bamboo shoots, mushrooms, bell pepper, and fried frog legs. Stir-fry 2 minutes.
Add sauce, toss to coat. Cook until sauce thickens, 1-2 minutes.
Drizzle with sesame oil and serve over steamed rice.

notes: Best eaten with chopsticks - meat slides right off the bones
Wood ear mushrooms add meaty texture but can be omitted
Find frog legs in Asian market freezer sections

recipes.title: Roast Chukar or Partridge
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Brined and roasted small game birds
recipes.description: Simple brined and roasted chukar partridge. The overnight brine keeps these lean birds juicy and gives you wiggle room during roasting.

instructions.text: Make brine: Pour hot water over salt, stir to dissolve. Add bay leaf, thyme, rosemary, sage, and cloves. Cool to room temperature.
Submerge birds in brine, cover, and refrigerate up to 8 hours.
Remove birds from brine, pat dry. Let sit uncovered in fridge several hours to dry the skin, or at room temperature 20 minutes.
Preheat oven to 450°F.
Stuff each bird cavity with a lemon quarter. Lightly salt exterior.
Lay celery stalks in a cast-iron pan to keep birds off the bottom.
Place birds on celery and roast 20-25 minutes.
Check temperature - breast meat should be 150-155°F, no higher. Pink is good.
Rest 5 minutes before serving.

notes: Never let breast meat exceed 155°F or it will be dry
Works for quail, small grouse, and Cornish game hens too
Only for plucked birds - don't use this recipe if skinned

recipes.title: Venison Steak Diane
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Classic sauce for venison medallions
recipes.description: Seared venison medallions with a rich brandy, mustard, and Worcestershire sauce. Named for Diana, goddess of the hunt.

instructions.text: Pat venison dry and season generously with salt and pepper. Let sit 10 minutes.
Melt 2 tbsp butter in a heavy pan over medium-high heat.
Sear venison, turning every minute, until nicely browned and medium-rare. Remove to rest.
Add remaining butter to pan with shallots and mushrooms. Sauté until starting to brown.
Add garlic and sauté 30 seconds.
Turn off heat and add brandy. Turn heat back to medium - this prevents flare-ups.
Cook until brandy is almost evaporated.
Add mustard, tomato paste, Worcestershire, and stock. Simmer 2 minutes.
Add cream if using. Taste and adjust seasoning.
Slice venison and serve with sauce. Garnish with parsley.

notes: Steak Diane originated with Escoffier and was named for the goddess of the hunt
Works with any venison - deer, elk, moose, caribou, antelope
Don't overcook venison - medium-rare is best

recipes.title: Roast Sharp-tailed Grouse with Rose Hip Glaze
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Prairies bird with prairies garnish
recipes.description: Sharp-tailed grouse roasted with a rose hip jelly glaze. The dark meat should be served pink, like doves.

instructions.text: Preheat oven to 450°F.
Season grouse inside and out with salt and pepper.
Mix rose hip jelly with butter and vinegar to make glaze.
Brush grouse liberally with glaze.
Roast for 15-20 minutes, basting with glaze halfway through.
Breast meat should be pink - about 135-140°F internal temperature.
Rest 5 minutes before serving.

notes: Sharp-tailed grouse are red meat and should be served pink like doves
Substitute currant jelly or crabapple jelly if no rose hip
From a cooking standpoint, these are essentially giant doves

recipes.title: Venison Liver and Onions
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Classic preparation with double-soak method
recipes.description: Deer liver and onions done right, with a double-soak method to tame any off-flavors. Best with livers from young animals.

instructions.text: First soak: Dissolve salt in water. Soak liver slices for 30 minutes.
Second soak: Drain and soak liver in milk for 1 hour or overnight.
Melt 2 tbsp butter in a large skillet over medium heat.
Add onions and cook slowly until caramelized, 15-20 minutes. Remove and keep warm.
Remove liver from milk, pat dry, and season with salt and pepper.
Dredge liver slices in flour, shaking off excess.
Add remaining butter to pan over medium-high heat.
Sear liver quickly, about 2 minutes per side for medium. Don't overcook.
Serve liver topped with caramelized onions and fresh thyme.

notes: Double soak (brine then dairy) removes off-flavors
Works with elk, pronghorn, caribou, or any large mammal liver
Best with livers from young animals

recipes.title: Braised Venison Tongue
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Slow braised deer or elk tongue
recipes.description: Tongue braised low and slow until tender, then peeled and sliced. Makes excellent tacos de lengua.

instructions.text: Place tongues in a pot with stock, vegetables, and aromatics.
Add enough water to cover if needed.
Bring to a simmer, cover, and place in 350°F oven.
Braise until a knife inserts easily, about 2-3 hours depending on size.
Let tongues cool in the braising liquid until cool enough to handle.
Peel the outer membrane off the tongues - it should slip off easily.
Slice and serve warm, or dice for tacos.
Strain and reserve braising liquid for reheating or as a sauce base.

notes: Peel the membrane when tongue is warm - it comes off easily
Great for tacos de lengua with cilantro and onion
Can be served cold sliced, or reheated in braising liquid

recipes.title: Peppered Dove Breasts (Doves au Poivre)
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - French classic adapted for dove
recipes.description: Dove breasts seared in butter with an easy pan sauce of shallots, brandy, cream, and peppercorns. Simple, fast, and delicious.

instructions.text: Salt dove breasts well and keep refrigerated until ready to cook.
Heat 3 tbsp butter in a skillet over medium-high heat.
Sear dove breasts 2 minutes on one side only. Remove to rest.
Add shallot to pan and sauté 1 minute.
Turn off heat and add brandy. Turn heat back to medium.
Add stock and both peppers. Simmer 2 minutes.
Add cream and simmer until slightly thickened.
Swirl in remaining 1 tbsp butter.
Spoon sauce over dove breasts and serve.

notes: Pepper is the dominant flavor - use freshly ground
Green peppercorns found near capers in most stores
Dove breast should be pink inside

recipes.title: Turkish Roast Pigeon with Bulgur
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Middle Eastern stuffed pigeon
recipes.description: Turkish-style roast pigeon stuffed with spiced bulgur wheat and walnuts. The Middle East cooks the best pigeon.

instructions.text: Brine pigeons: dissolve salt in water, submerge birds, refrigerate 6-12 hours.
Make stuffing: Bring stock to simmer with cinnamon, cardamom, allspice, and 1 tsp salt. Add bulgur, cover, simmer 15 minutes.
Meanwhile, heat oil and fry onions and walnuts until colored.
Combine cooked bulgur with onion-walnut mixture. Cool slightly, then add mint and lemon juice.
Remove pigeons from brine, pat dry, and stuff loosely with bulgur mixture.
Preheat oven to 350°F.
Place celery stalks in pan, lay pigeons breast-side down on celery. Roast 25 minutes.
Turn birds over and roast 10 more minutes.
Increase heat to 500°F and roast 10 minutes to brown and crisp.
Serve on remaining bulgur with lemon juice and fleur de sel.

notes: Brining keeps lean wild pigeons from drying out
Can substitute ptarmigan, sharp-tailed grouse, or Cornish hens
Goes well with raki or medium-bodied red wine

recipes.title: Pigeon Tortellini
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Stuffed pasta with ground pigeon
recipes.description: Morsels of pasta stuffed with ground pigeon, sweet wine, herbs, and roasted garlic, served with a juniper butter sauce.

instructions.text: Make filling: Mix ground pigeon with roasted garlic, wine, herbs, Parmesan, salt, pepper, and egg.
Cut pasta into 3-inch squares.
Place small spoonful of filling in center of each square.
Fold corner to corner to make triangle, pressing edges to seal.
Wrap around finger and pinch corners together to form tortellini shape.
Bring large pot of salted water to boil.
Meanwhile, make sauce: Melt butter with juniper berries, add stock, simmer 5 minutes.
Cook tortellini until they float, about 3-4 minutes.
Toss with juniper butter sauce and extra Parmesan.

notes: Can substitute dove, pheasant, or duck for pigeon
Juniper adds a piney, gin-like note to the butter
Can make tortellini ahead and freeze

recipes.title: Sichuan Crispy Fried Carp
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - When life gives you carp, think East
recipes.description: Chinese-style whole fried carp - crispy and delicious. Carp is prized in Asia, and this is an excellent way to prepare it.

instructions.text: Score the fish in a crosshatch pattern on both sides, cutting to the bone.
Pat fish very dry and dust heavily with cornstarch, getting into all the cuts.
Heat oil in wok or deep pot to 375°F.
Carefully lower fish into oil and fry until golden and crispy, about 8-10 minutes. Keep oil temperature up.
Remove fish to a platter.
Pour off all but 2 tbsp oil. Add ginger, garlic, chiles, and Sichuan peppercorns. Stir-fry 30 seconds.
Add wine, soy sauce, vinegar, sugar, and stock. Simmer 2 minutes.
Pour sauce over fish and top with green onions.

notes: Works with any whole fish that fits in a wok
Scoring helps the fish cook evenly and get crispy
Carp is prized in Asian cuisines

recipes.title: Catfish Étouffée (Smothered Catfish)
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Cajun smothered catfish
recipes.description: Cajun smothered catfish in a rich tomato and pepper sauce. A wonderful way to celebrate this fish.

instructions.text: Melt butter in a large skillet over medium heat.
Add onion, celery, and bell pepper. Sauté until soft, about 8 minutes.
Add garlic and sauté 1 minute.
Stir in flour and cook 2 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add tomato paste and tomatoes. Cook 3 minutes.
Pour in stock and add Cajun seasoning and cayenne. Simmer 10 minutes.
Add catfish chunks and simmer gently until fish is cooked, about 8-10 minutes.
Stir in green onions and parsley.
Serve over steamed rice.

notes: Can add small shrimp or crawfish 5 minutes before end
Don't stir too vigorously or fish will break up
Use any fresh catfish - wild or farmed

recipes.title: Wild Turkey Carnitas
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Braised and crisped turkey for tacos
recipes.description: The perfect solution for tough wild turkey legs. Braised until tender, then shredded and crisped in lard for tacos.

instructions.text: Place turkey pieces in a large Dutch oven with stock, onion, garlic, bay leaves, oregano, cumin, and salt.
Add enough water to cover the meat.
Bring to a simmer, then cook gently until meat is very tender - 90 minutes for domestic, up to 4 hours for old wild tom.
Remove turkey and let cool. Reserve cooking liquid.
Shred meat off the bones, discarding tendons and cartilage.
When ready to serve, heat lard in a large skillet over high heat.
Add shredded meat and let sit without stirring until one side is crispy and browned.
Stir and repeat if desired for more crispy bits.
Serve in warm tortillas with lime, onion, cilantro, and salsa.

notes: The shredded meat keeps for a week in the fridge before crisping
Also works with pheasant, old chicken, or guinea hen
Crisp only the portion you're serving

recipes.title: BBQ Turkey Legs with Maple-Bourbon Sauce
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Barbecued wild turkey thighs
recipes.description: Slow-smoked turkey legs with a homemade maple-bourbon barbecue sauce. Thighs work better than drumsticks since they have fewer tough tendons.

instructions.text: Coat turkey thighs with dry rub and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or overnight.
Make the sauce: Combine ketchup, maple syrup, bourbon, vinegar, Worcestershire, paprika, garlic powder, and cayenne in a saucepan. Simmer 10 minutes.
Set up smoker or grill for indirect heat at 275°F.
Smoke thighs until internal temperature reaches 165°F, about 2-3 hours.
During the last 30 minutes, brush with barbecue sauce every 10 minutes.
Let rest 10 minutes before serving with extra sauce.

notes: Thighs are preferred over drumsticks - fewer tendons
Can also be done in oven at 275°F with liquid smoke
Works with store-bought or wild turkey

recipes.title: Homemade Andouille Sausage
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Cajun smoked sausage
recipes.description: A heavily seasoned Cajun sausage, almost always smoked. Can be made with any meat - pork, venison, bear, or beef.

instructions.text: Chill meat and fat in freezer until very cold but not frozen, about 30 minutes.
Grind meat and fat through coarse die (6-7mm).
Mix ground meat with all seasonings and powdered milk.
Add ice water and mix thoroughly until the mixture is tacky and binds together.
Stuff into hog casings, twisting into 6-inch links.
Let sausages dry uncovered in refrigerator overnight.
Set up smoker with pecan or other hardwood at 175-200°F.
Smoke until internal temperature reaches 150°F, about 3-4 hours.
Fully cook before eating by grilling, pan-frying, or adding to gumbo.

notes: Can use venison, bear, beef, or any meat
Pecan is traditional wood for smoking andouille
Smoked sausages can be frozen after smoking and before final cooking

recipes.title: Louisiana Boudin
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Cajun rice and meat sausage
recipes.description: A cooked sausage with meat, liver, rice, and Cajun seasonings. A Louisiana favorite that's loosely stuffed into casings.

instructions.text: Place meat, liver, fat, onion, celery, pepper, garlic, and bay leaf in a pot. Cover with water.
Simmer until meat is very tender, about 1.5 hours. Reserve cooking liquid.
Remove bay leaf. Grind everything through coarse die.
Add ground mixture to a large bowl with salt and Cajun seasoning.
Add cooked rice, parsley, and green onions.
Add up to 4 cups reserved cooking liquid and mix 3-5 minutes until cohesive but still loose.
Stuff loosely into hog casings, twist into 8-inch links.
Poach in salted water at 165-170°F for 10 minutes.
Serve immediately, or grill until casing is crispy.

notes: Everything is cooked before stuffing - a 'cooked sausage'
Can also be formed into balls and fried (boudin balls)
Best grilled so casing gets crispy
Works with duck, turkey, venison, or pork

recipes.title: Country-Style Venison Sausage
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Rich sausage with bay and garlic
recipes.description: A rich country-style venison sausage where ground bay leaves and garlic are the dominant flavors. Especially good for grilling.

instructions.text: Grind bay leaves to powder in a spice grinder.
Mix all seasonings together.
Grind very cold venison and fat through coarse die.
Add seasonings and ice water to ground meat.
Mix by hand or with paddle attachment until mixture is tacky, about 2 minutes.
Fry a small patty to test seasoning. Adjust salt if needed.
Stuff into hog casings, twisting into 5-6 inch links.
Refrigerate overnight uncovered to dry casings.
Grill, pan-fry, or use in other recipes.

notes: Keep meat and fat very cold for best texture
Bay leaves must be ground to powder - whole bay leaf bits are unpleasant
Especially good on the grill

recipes.title: Polish Duck Sausages
recipes.source_note: From honest-food.net - Fine-grained emulsified sausage
recipes.description: A fine-grained, almost emulsified sausage like a real Polish kielbasa, but with duck as the dominant meat. Snow goose would be perfect here too.

instructions.text: Chill all meat and fat in freezer until very firm but not frozen.
Grind meat and fat through fine die (4mm).
Put ground meat in mixer with paddle. Add all seasonings and powdered milk.
Mix on low while adding ice water. Continue until mixture becomes sticky and emulsified, about 5 minutes.
Stuff into hog casings, twisting into 6-inch links.
Poach in 170°F water until internal temperature reaches 150°F, about 45 minutes.
Chill in ice water to stop cooking.
Grill or pan-fry before serving.

notes: Fine grind and emulsification create the smooth kielbasa texture
Snow goose works perfectly
Marjoram is essential for Polish flavor
